summary: On May 21, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment against a Texas-based health care company and its CEO for violating the antifraud provisions of the federal health care law.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in the District of Columbia, alleges that, from 1973 until 2008, the federal government issued a rule requiring health care providers to perform abortions and sterilizations.  According to the complaint, this rule violated the federal anti-discrimination provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, the company and CEO consented to the entry of the final judgment, which permanently enjoins them from violating these provisions and orders them to pay a civil penalty in the amount of $10,000.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of California today announced criminal charges against the company, its CEO, and a member of the board of directors of the company.  To learn more about anti-fraud provisions in the federal securities laws, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-221 (January 21, 2020).  The complaint also alleges that the federal district court in Jackson, Mississippi, issued an order requiring the company to comply with the proposed rule, which is subject to court approval.  On May 22, 2020, the court granted the company's request for a temporary restraining order and ordered it to provide an accounting of its assets, including any assets that may be located outside the jurisdiction of the court.  A hearing on the matter was scheduled for May 24, 2020.  For further information on the subject of this matter, see Judgment No. 13-20-20 (January 20, 2020) and Order No. 12-20(a)(1) and (3) (4) thereunder, the SEC complaint, the Department of Justice's Office of Inspector General, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Internal Revenue Service's Criminal Investigations, and the Office of the Chief of the Public Health Inspector General's Office. Â The SEC's continuing investigation is being conducted by Mark Dee and supervised by Eric R. Werner of the Boston Regional Office.Â  The litigation will be led by Mr. Dee and Ms. Werner.   The case is being supervised by C.J. Kerstetter.   The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Texas Department of Health and Human Services, the FBI, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, the California Department of Insurance, the Florida Department of Banking and Securities, the Missouri Secretary of State's Office, the Pennsylvania Department of Commerce, the Virginia Department of Consumer Affairs, the
